clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
Famous for its pasta, pizza, and a small country within it.
fun_fact: Rome has a country inside it: Vatican City, the smallest country in the world.
There are more than 1,500 fountains in Rome!
trivia: The Colosseum could hold between 50,000 to 80,000 spectators.
Romans used to clean their clothes using fermented urine as a detergent!

clues: This city has a famous opera house shaped like sails.
Known for its beautiful harbor and iconic bridge.
fun_fact: Sydney’s Opera House took 14 years to build and was originally estimated to cost $7 million but ended up costing $102 million!
Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world and attracts millions of visitors every year.
trivia: Sydney was the first European settlement in Australia, established in 1788.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is the world's largest steel arch bridge.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
This city sits on the banks of the longest river in the world.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years!
Cairo is known as the 'City of a Thousand Minarets' because of its many mosques.
trivia: The Nile River runs through Cairo, spanning over 6,600 kilometers.
Egyptians invented one of the earliest forms of paper using papyrus.

clues: This city is famous for its massive carnival celebration every year.
Home to a giant statue of Christ overlooking the city.
fun_fact: Rio’s Christ the Redeemer statue is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World!
The city's beaches, like Copacabana and Ipanema, are world-famous.
trivia: Rio de Janeiro was once the capital of Brazil until 1960.
The name 'Rio de Janeiro' means 'River of January' in Portuguese.

clues: This city has a famous clock tower known as Big Ben.
Home to the British monarch and a giant Ferris wheel.
fun_fact: London has over 170 museums, including the British Museum which houses over 8 million works.
The London Underground is the oldest underground railway network in the world.
trivia: London was originally called Londinium by the Romans.
The Shard is the tallest building in the UK, standing at 310 meters.

clues: This city is known for its colorful onion-domed cathedral.
Home to the Kremlin and Red Square.
fun_fact: Moscow's metro stations are often referred to as 'underground palaces' due to their ornate designs.
The Moscow Kremlin is the largest active fortress in Europe.
trivia: Moscow is the northernmost and coldest megacity on Earth.
The city has more billionaires than any other city in the world.

clues: This city is home to the Forbidden City and the Great Wall.
Known for its historic palaces and temples.
fun_fact: Beijing has seven UNESCO World Heritage Sites, the most of any city in the world.
The city hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics and will host the 2022 Winter Olympics.
trivia: Beijing means 'Northern Capital' in Mandarin.
The Forbidden City is the largest ancient palatial structure in the world.

clues: This city is known for its ultramodern architecture and luxury shopping.
Home to the tallest building in the world.
fun_fact: Dubai's Burj Khalifa stands at 828 meters tall, making it the tallest building in the world.
The city has a police force that uses supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.
trivia: Dubai has the world's largest shopping mall, the Dubai Mall.
The city has an indoor ski resort located inside a shopping mall.

clues: This city straddles two continents, Europe and Asia.
Known for its historic sites like the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque.
fun_fact: Istanbul was formerly known as Byzantium and Constantinople.
The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the largest and oldest covered markets in the world.
trivia: Istanbul is the only city in the world located on two continents.
The city has over 3,000 mosques.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant street life and ornate temples.
Home to the Grand Palace and Wat Arun.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world.

trivia: Bangkok is the most visited city in the world, attracting over 20 million tourists annually.

clues: This city is known for its stunning Table Mountain.
